cmCourseInfo.description: A brief introductory survey of psychology as both a biological and social science. Topics will include physiological, learning, perceptual, motivational, cognitive, developmental, personality, abnormal, and social psychology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Throughout the term, students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos. There will be two online term tests (each scheduled on a specific day and available for 24 hours) as well as an in-person, on-campus final exam (scheduled on a specific day by the Faculty of Arts and Sciences during the final exam period).  Support will be offered in the form of study guides, virtual office hours and online tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals of descriptive and inferential statistics, including population and sampling distributions, simple association, probability, estimation, and hypothesis testing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statistics I

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals of statistical analysis of experimental and observational data including linear models, the analysis of variance, a priori contrasts, post-hoc tests, power analysis and effect size calculations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statistics II

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an introduction to conceiving, designing, and conducting research in psychology. It prepares students to be both consumers and producers of scientific research, and also addresses basic issues related to the work of psychological scientists such as theory development, research ethics, and scientific writing. Students in this course will gain insight into the scientific process as a whole – its advantages, difficulties, and limitations. As such, students will be able to better evaluate the knowledge that psychological science can provide, and integrate that knowledge into a broader worldview.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychological Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/ PSY100Y5/ (PSYA01H3, PSYA02H3)/ COG250Y1

Midterms will be conducted on Quercus during the last 2 hours (2pm-4pm) of class time on the dates under Course Evaluation (Thursday May 16th, June 3rd, & June 17th). Papers will be handed in through Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Concepts, theories, and applications of classical and contemporary learning theories, including classical and operant conditioning. Current theories of the physiological and anatomical basis of learning and memory, including synaptic plasticity, the role of the hippocampus, amygdala, frontal cortex and other brain regions. Theories will be related to a practical understanding and applications such as drug addiction, phobias and other disorders.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Learning and Plasticity
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/PSY100Y5/PSYA01H3/COG250Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to research and theory on the neural and cognitive architecture of attention, memory, language, thinking and reasoning.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the physiological and psychological basis of perception across the different sensory modalities in humans and lower animals, with an emphasis on vision. Exploring visual perception such as shape and objects, scenes, colour, space, and motion as well as auditory perception of simple and complex sounds, and location. Further topics may include touch, including perception of temperature, pain and body posture, the chemical senses, and cross-modal influences of the senses on one another. In-class demonstrations may supplement the lectures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Sensation and Perception
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/PSY100Y5/PSYA01H3/COG250Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

Learning progress will be assessed after each of five modules. All assessments completed during the semester will be conducted online, as will the final exam/assessment.

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides students with a solid background in the biological basis of behaviour. Animal and human research topics will include functional neuroanatomy and neural signalling. Further topics may include sensory and motor control, motivational systems, hormones, and emotions, among other topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Behavioural Neuroscience
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/ PSY100Y5/ PSYA01H3/ COG250Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: Special Topics in Psychology for the Summer Abroad Program. Course topics, content, and instructor may vary from one year to another. More information about Psychology course offerings can be obtained from the Professional & International Programs office at Woodsworth College. For students in any Psychology and/or Social Science major or specialist.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Psychology Abroad
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 8.0 credits

cmCourseInfo.description: Age changes in sensory and perceptual processes, motor skill, learning, memory, and personality. Theory, methodological problems, social, cultural, and environmental influences that shape behaviour and attitudes towards and among the elderly.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychology of Aging
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, PSY210H1/ PSY210H5/ PSYB20H3

The class conducts an original research project, including design, data collection, data analysis, and a written report. Course capacity is limited to 15 students and priority is given to PSY Specialists and Research Specialists during the first enrolment period.

cmCourseInfo.description: Intensive study of social attitude development, description, measurement, modification, and organization.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course.  Lectures will be given as 2-3 hour online videos posted to Quercus and discussion/participation will be completed on Slack. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides, and use Quercus for submission of discussion posts and assignments.  The final exam will be in person, so students will need to come to campus to write it.

subjectPost.name: Psychology of Economics and Management Certificate

cmCourseInfo.description: One of the hallmarks of human behaviour is its diversity. Some of the ways in which we differ are thought to be relatively idiosyncratic (e.g., specific aspects of personality), whereas others are fairly systematic. Cultural psychology is one area of research in human behaviour that examines systematic differences resulting from individuals’ cultural backgrounds. This course will introduce you to the consideration of cultural variation in the study of human thought and behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cross-Cultural Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, PSY220H1/ PSY220H5/ PSYB10H3/ SOC213H1

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals with psychological issues in the law, with particular reference to criminal law. It focuses mainly on research that has been done on pretrial publicity, eyewitness testimony, rules of evidence, and other factors that might affect jury decisions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychology and the Law
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, PSY220H1/ PSY220H5/ PSYB10H3/ SOC213H1

Lectures will be delivered as recorded content the week before the set online Companion Lecture. The midterm will be conducted on Quercus during the first 2 hours (4pm-6pm) of class time on the dates under Course Evaluation (May 23rd). The final will be 4-7pm on June 17th. Papers will be handed in through Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines research evidence concerning the impact of psychological factors on physical health and illness.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, (PSY230H1/ PSY230H5/ PSYB30H3)/ (PSY240H1/ PSY240H5/ PSYB32H3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online course with an in-person final exam. Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. There will be opportunities for live discussion with the instructor and/or TA during scheduled Zoom meetings. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or Powerpoint slides and use Quercus for submission of the assignments and online midterm test. The final exam will be in-person during the final exam period. There will not be a remote option for completing the final exam: Students must be able to attend the in-person final exam at the University during the final exam period to complete this course.

subjectPost.name: Psychology of Economics and Management Certificate

cmCourseInfo.description: A review of the field of positive psychology, which is the study of happiness and fulfillment. Topics include personal growth, meaning, hedonic and eudaimonic approaches to well-being, gratitude, awe, flow states, mindfulness and meditation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Positive Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, (PSY220H1/ PSY220H5/ PSYB10H3/ SOC213H1)/ (PSY230H1/ PSY230H5/ PSYB30H3)/ (PSY240H1/ PSY240H5/ PSYB32H3)

cmCourseInfo.description: Work in psychological disorders has increasingly used the theories and methodologies of cognitive psychology to guide research. This course will examine accounts of clinical disorders informed by cognitive experimental psychology, with emphasis on recent work in affective disorders.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cognition and Psychopathology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, (PSY230H1/ PSY230H5/ PSYB30H3)/ (PSY240H1/ PSY240H5/ PSYB32H3), (PSY270H1/ COG250Y1/ PSY270H5/ PSYB57H3)

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines various theories of how personality functioning may become impaired and corresponding psychotherapeutic interventions. Emphasis on empirical assessment of personality dysfunction and therapy effectiveness.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theories of Psychopathology and Psychotherapy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, (PSY230H1/ PSY230H5/ PSYB30H3)/ (PSY240H1/ PSY240H5/ PSYB32H3)

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at https://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/academics/research-opportunities/research-opportunities-program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

cmCourseInfo.description: A single semester intensive laboratory or applied research project for students who seek hands-on research experience to complement our regular course offerings. Each project culminates in a scholarly paper and oral presentation. Students must secure a faculty supervisor from the Dept. of Psychology and submit a completed application form that includes details about the project before the start of the semester. Application forms are available on the Department’s website (https://psych.utoronto.ca/programs-and-courses/undergraduate-course-information) and must be emailed to the undergraduate office (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca) by the end of the first week of September for fall projects, the start of the second week in January for winter projects. If you’re registering for a summer project, please submit it by the beginning of the first week in May. This course is open to all students.
cmCourseInfo.title: Individual Projects
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY202H1/ ECO220Y1/ SOC252H1/ STA221H1/ PSY202H5/ STA221H5/ PSYC08H3/ STAB27H3/ STAC32H3, and the appropriate background in Psychology for the proposed work (e.g., PSY210H1 if the project is in the area of Developmental Psychology)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For PSY405H1 and 406H1, 'E' indicator: Students must first obtain consent of a faculty member in the Department to supervise their project.  Information and application form is available on our website at https://psych.utoronto.ca/current-program-students/undergraduate-courses.  The electronic application form, signed by both student and supervisor, should be submitted to the Undergraduate Administrator for approval via email (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca).  Please note that during the summer projects are only worth 0.5 credits.

cmCourseInfo.description: A single semester intensive laboratory or applied research project for students who seek hands-on research experience to complement our regular course offerings. Each project culminates in a scholarly paper and oral presentation. Students must secure a faculty supervisor from the Dept. of Psychology and submit a completed application form that includes details about the project before the start of the semester. Application forms are available on the Department’s website (https://psych.utoronto.ca/programs-and-courses/undergraduate-course-information) and must be emailed to the undergraduate office (psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca) by the end of the first week of September for fall projects, the start of the second week in January for winter projects. If you’re registering for a summer project, please submit it by the beginning of the first week in May. This course is open to all students.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY202H1/ ECO220Y1/ SOC252H1/ STA221H1/ PSY202H5/ STA221H5/ PSYC08H3/ STAB27H3/ STAC32H3, and the appropriate background in Psychology for the proposed work (e.g., PSY210H1 if the project is in the area of Developmental Psychology)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is restricted to two groups of students. Group 1 is given priority access until March 3. Beginning March 4, Group 2 can enrol in this course.
Group 1:ASSPE1160 - SP PSYCHOLOGY
Group 1:ASSPE1958 - SP PSYCHOLOGY RESEARCH(THESIS)
Group 2:ASMAJ1160 - MA PSYCHOLOGY
Group 2:ASMIN1160 - MI PSYCHOLOGY

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course focuses on the social psychology of interpersonal relationships between individuals, especially romantic or close relationships and friendships. It surveys what social psychologists have learned about the development, maintenance, disruption or dissolution of personal relationships, as well as current social psychological theories of interpersonal relationships.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology of Interpersonal Relationships
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, PSY220H1/ PSY220H5/ PSYB10H3/ SOC213H1

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth examination of current research and selected topics in cognitive psychology. Content in any given year depends on the instructor. Course capacity is limited to 20 students and enrolment priority is given to PSY Specialists and Research Specialists. There may be additional prerequisites based on the seminar topic given.
cmCourseInfo.title: Seminar in Cognition
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY202H1/ECO220Y1/SOC252H1/STA221H1/PSY202H5/STA221H5/PSYC08H3/STAB27H3/STAC32H3, and PSY270H1/PSY270H5/PSYB57H3/COG250Y1

subjectPost.name: Cognitive Science Major - Arts: Perception and Attention Stream
Cognitive Science Major - Arts: Language and Cognition Stream
Cognitive Science Major - Arts: Thinking and Reasoning Stream
Cognitive Science Major - Science: Computational Cognition Stream
Cognitive Science Major - Science: Cognition and the Brain Stream

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a capstone lecture course surveying research on how the mind arises from the brain. The first objective of the course is to understand how processes in human brains (ranging from the firing of a single neuron to the dynamics of billions) support cognitive abilities (such as recognizing a face, remembering a birthday from childhood, understanding the words in a spoken lecture, or planning a route home from class). The second objective of the course is to understand the methods of contemporary cognitive neuroscience research, to enable students to read primary literature and to understand ongoing debates.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cognitive Neuroscience
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY201H1/ ECO220Y1/ EEB225H1/ GGR270H1/ IRW220H1/ POL222H1/ SOC202H1/ STA220H1/ STA238H1/ STA248H1/ STA288H1/ PSY201H5/ STA215H5/ STA220H5/ PSYB07H3/ STAB22H3/ STAB23H3/ STAB57H3, (PSY260H1/ PSYB38H3)/ (PSY270H1/ PSY270H5/ PSYB57H3/ COG250Y1)/ (PSY290H1/ PSY290H5/ PSYB64H3/ HMB200H1/ PSL300H1)
